Opera

* 'ANDREA CHÉNIER' (Tomorrow and Wednesday) Ben Heppner, arguably the leading Wagnerian tenor of our day, continues his bold explorations of far-flung repertory with the title role of Giordano's swashbuckling verismo opera, in the Metropolitan Opera's revival of Nicolas Joël's 1996 production. Mr. Heppner may lack the vocal colorings and idiomatic expressivity of the heroic Italian tenors who excelled in this touchstone role, that of a poet with libertarian fervor during the French Revolution. But in his honest and compelling portrayal he sings with burnished sound, vigor and lyrical sensitivity. The rich-voiced soprano Violeta Urmana sings Maddalena for the final performance on Wednesday night, but the popular soprano Aprile Millo takes over the role tomorrow. The stentorian baritone Juan Pons sings Gérard. At 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $42 to $220 tomorrow, $15 to $175 for Wednesday. (Anthony Tommasini)

* 'CURLEW RIVER' (Tonight and tomorrow night) Britten called his one-act opera ''Curlew River'' a church parable. Inspired by a Japanese Noh play, the work takes the form of a sacred ritual, with a procession of monks enacting a mystery play about a madwoman who crosses a river with a ferryman in search of her abducted son. The Japan Society offers a staging of this haunting and seldom-seen work, a co-production with L'Opéra de Rouen/Haute-Normandie. Directed by Yoshi Oida, it stars the tenor Michael Bennett as the madwoman, with musical direction by David Stern. At 7:30, 333 East 47th Street, Manhattan, (212) 715-1258, japansociety.org; $52; $45 for members. (Tommasini)

'FLAVIO' (Tomorrow) Candy pink and candy green set the tone for Chas Rader-Shieber's antic production of an opera that consists of arias nestled side by side, bright and sweet as a box of fondants: much of a good thing, leaving a reasonably pleasant aftertaste. On the first night of the City Opera revival, the singers seemed to be fighting to find their pitches: making company debuts are Katherine Rohrer, a light mezzo with a nice tone who didn't quite find her feet on the first note; Gerald Thompson, a promising but sometimes wild countertenor; and the conductor William Lacey, who led a strong, lithe performance. David Walker did a fine job as the foppish, foolish king of the title. At 1:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $25 to $125. (Anne Midgette)

* 'GIULIO CESARE' (Tonight and Tuesday) The auditorium of the Metropolitan Opera may be too big for Handel. But the cast that has been assembled for the company's revival of ''Giulio Cesare'' is so exceptional that the lack of intimacy does not matter. With a score of astounding richness and variety, the opera emerges as an affecting and psychologically astute masterpiece. With his alluring voice, the countertenor David Daniels excels in the daunting title role. The soprano Ruth Ann Swenson makes a vocally exquisite Cleopatra. Patricia Bardon, a rich-toned Irish mezzo-soprano, brings noble bearing and lyrical elegance to the role of Cornelia. Harry Bicket elicits a surprisingly stylish account of the score from the orchestra. The downside is John Copley's tacky production. At 7:30, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $15 to $205. (Tommasini)

'MADAMA BUTTERFLY' (Tomorrow and Wednesday) East-West relations go south in Puccini's famous melodrama. Shu-Ying Li sings Cio-Cio-San, and Christopher Jackson is Lieutenant Pinkerton in this New York City Opera production. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; sold out tomorrow;$25 to $115 for Wednesday. (Bernard Holland)

'TURANDOT' (Tomorrow, Monday and Thursday) For spectacle and big music, the Franco Zeffirelli production of Puccini's final opera, at the Met, is hard to beat. For compelling leads, you might have to look elsewhere: Andrea Gruber sounded wobbly and thin on the first night of this revival, and Richard Margison effortful, though he marshaled his forces for ''Nessun dorma.'' Only Hei-Kyung Hong's Liù, with her reliably floating pianos, was really worth the price of admission. But spectacle and size are evidently enough to keep tickets selling briskly for this one. Marco Armiliato conducts. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., Monday and Thursday at 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; sold out tomorrow and Thursday; $175 tickets remain for Monday. (Midgette)

'DIE ZAUBERFLÖTE' (Tonight and tomorrow night) The last two performances of this new look at the Mozart favorite by the South African director William Kentridge and the Belgian opera house La Monnaie. At 7:30, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100, bam.org; $40 to $125. (Holland)
Classical Music

AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA (Sunday) Franz Schreker's much-discussed and little-heard opera ''Der Ferne Klang'' is taken up by the enterprising Leon Botstein in this concert performance. At 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $27 to $55. (Holland)

CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER (Sunday and Tuesday) Nicholas Maw is one of the Chamber Music Society's 2006-7 ''season composers.'' Here the society presents his ''Roman Canticle,'' a setting of Robert Browning's poem ''Two in the Campagna,'' for mezzo-soprano, flute, viola and harp. Angelika Kirchschlager, the mezzo-soprano originally scheduled to perform the work, has been replaced by Peggy Kriha Dye, a soprano. The program also includes Charles Martin Loeffler's ''Quatre Poems'' for voice, viola and piano; Dvorak's Piano Trio in E minor; and Mendelssohn's String Quintet No. 1. Sunday at 5 p.m., Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org; $28 to $50. (Vivien Schweitzer)

NELSON FREIRE (Thursday) New York audiences experience Mr. Freire's pianism only in glimpses, but this Brazilian returns to the Metropolitan Museum of Art with Bach, Beethoven and Chopin standards, Debussy's ''Children's Corner Suite'' and excerpts from Albéniz's ''Iberia.'' At 8 p.m., (212) 570-3949, metmuseum.org; $50. (Holland)

* OSVALDO GOLIJOV/DAWN UPSHAW YOUNG ARTISTS CONCERT (Tomorrow and Sunday) To foster collaboration between singers and composers, the soprano Dawn Upshaw, through the auspices of Carnegie Hall's Weill Music Institute, has presented joint workshops with leading composers, notably John Harbison in 2004 and Osvaldo Golijov this season. A roster of young composers, paired with young singers, has been collaborating in these workshops for some months, under the guidance of Mr. Golijov and Ms. Upshaw. The resulting works will be presented this weekend in two very affordable programs. Needless to say, each piece will be receiving its world premiere. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $15. (Tommasini)

KALICHSTEIN-LAREDO-ROBINSON TRIO (Sunday) This venerable piano trio is celebrating its 30th anniversary since making its debut in 1977 at the White House for President Jimmy Carter's inauguration. On Sunday it performs Leon Kirchner's Trio No. 2 and is joined by the violist Pinchas Zukerman for Mozart's Piano Quartet in E flat (K. 493), and by the double bassist Harold Robinson for Schubert's ''Trout'' Quintet. At 2 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $23 to $75. (Schweitzer)

* OLIVER KNUSSEN (Tonight) This British composer has a significant body of bracing and inventive scores to his credit. But in the last decade or so he has had a woeful record of meeting deadlines for commissioned pieces. An ambitious new work for the pianist Peter Serkin and a large chamber ensemble was supposed to have had its long-awaited premiere tonight at Zankel Hall. Alas, Mr. Knussen was not able to complete the score. In its place he will offer his ''Requiem -- Songs for Sue,'' a New York premiere. The program, featuring Mr. Serkin, the soprano Susan Narucki and the Zankel Band, boosted here to the size of a chamber orchestra, still looks enticing, with works by Messiaen, Magnus Lindberg and Julian Anderson. And Mr. Knussen is an accomplished conductor, which has been one of the problems, actually: his conducting has taken time from his composing. At 7:30, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $25 and $35. (Tommasini)

* KARITA MATTILA (Wednesday) She's been called the leading lyric soprano of her generation -- though that was before she took on ''Fidelio'' and ''Salome'' -- and praised for her lied interpretations, particularly of Finnish song, represented by one set on this thoughtful and wide-ranging concert. The other pieces are Barber's ''Hermit Songs,'' a set of Wolf songs and Turina's ''Poema en Forma de Canciones.'' Martin Katz is the pianist. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $25 to $84. (Midgette)

NETHERLANDS BACH SOCIETY (Wednesday) The Netherlands Bach Society, a period-instrument ensemble founded in 1921, says it is the oldest early-music group still performing in that country. On Wednesday Jos Van Veldhoven, its artistic director, leads the ensemble and soloists -- including the sopranos Dorothee Mields and Johanette Zomer, the alto Matthew White, the tenor Charles Daniels and the bass Peter Harvey -- in Bach's monumental Mass in B minor. At 8 p.m., Metropolitan Museum of Art, (212) 570-3949, metmuseum.org; $50. (Schweitzer)

NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC (Today and tomorrow) Sakari Oramo conducts the orchestra in Sibelius's Sixth Symphony. Lisa Batiashvili is the soloist for Shostakovich's First Violin Concerto. Today at 11 a.m., tomorrow at 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nyphil.org; $24 to $79. (Holland)

* ORPHEUS CHAMBER ORCHESTRA (Tomorrow) A new piece by Ingram Marshall is a good reason to go to a concert. Perhaps the only reason Mr. Marshall is not better known is that he's not played more, and the Cheswatyr New Music Initiative, which teamed up with Orpheus and WNYC to commission ''Orphic Memories,'' is doing its bit to change that by ensuring that this piece is played on the orchestra's tour and broadcast. As for the music: think Romantic sensibility and lushness filtered through an electronics sensibility. The conductorless ensemble is adding to the program Gil Shaham in the Beethoven Violin Concerto, as well as Mendelssohn's Sinfonia No. 10. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $30 to $88. (Midgette)

* POCKET CONCERTOS (Tomorrow) Miller Theater presents the second installment of its innovative Pocket Concertos series, a three-year project commissioning 12 composers to write 12 concertos. The lineup tomorrow features ''Spin 5,'' a five-movement violin piece by Charles Wuorinen performed by Jennifer Koh; ''People Mountain People Sea,'' a cello work by Huang Ruo performed by Jian Wang; Anthony Davis's ''You Have the Right to Remain Silent,'' for clarinet, performed by J. D. Parran; and Sebastian Currier's Piano Concerto, with Emma Tahmizian. Brad Lubman leads the Perspectives Ensemble. At 8 p.m., Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 854-7799, millertheater.com; $25; $15 for students. (Schweitzer)

CHRISTOPHE ROUSSET (Thursday) Call it ''Family Ties'': the concert by this master harpsichordist features music by Louis Couperin and his nephew, the better-known François, and by Johann Sebastian Bach and one of his most famous sons, Carl Philipp Emanuel. François's harpsichord music represents an acme of the French style; Mr. Rousset will play a linked group of five pieces, or ordre, from the last of his four books of collected harpsichord works. From the Bachs, the offerings are the French Suite No. 3 by the father, and the third of the seminal ''Württemberg'' sonatas by the son. At 7:30 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $40. (Midgette)

* UBS VERBIER FESTIVAL CHAMBER ORCHESTRA (Thursday) This chamber orchestra, whose members are chosen from the best current members and alumni of the UBS Verbier Festival Orchestra, will perform Mozart concertos with the first-rate violinist Maxim Vengerov as soloist and conductor. The program includes the Violin Concertos Nos. 2 and 4 (K. 211 and 218), with Mr. Vengerov's own cadenzas, and the Sinfonia Concertante in E flat (K. 364), with the violist Lawrence Power -- repertory this group recently recorded for a new disc on EMI. The concert also includes Shostakovich's Chamber Symphony. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $30 to $98. (Schweitzer)

YOUNG CONCERT ARTISTS IRENE DIAMOND CONCERT (Wednesday) Young Concert Artists discovers talented instrumentalists, singers and composers through yearly auditions; the organization then presents them in concerts and assists in managing their careers. The group's annual Irene Diamond Concert spotlights two pianists and a flutist. Chu-Fang Huang plays Grieg's Piano Concerto in A minor; Dora Seres plays Mozart's Flute Concerto in G; and Gleb Ivanov performs Prokofiev's Piano Concerto No. 3. Scott Yoo, an alumnus of the group, conducts the Orchestra of St. Luke's. At 7:30 p.m., Rose Theater, Broadway at 60th Street, (212) 307-6656, yca.org; $15 to 35. (Schweitzer)

* AILEY II (Tonight through Sunday; Wednesday and Thursday) Alvin Ailey created a second, or junior, company in 1974, almost casually, as a way of working on new choreography. Ailey II is now a world-class troupe, filled with dancers who are not only good but also capable of performing with a youthful hunger for their art, as well as with a reverence for dance that is a part of the mission of the company director, Sylvia Waters, whom Ailey himself chose to direct that first group. Now Ailey II is coming home, performing in the black-box theater that is part of the Ailey headquarters: newer, grander and more gleaming than Ailey ever envisioned. The repertory will include new dances by Abdel Salaam, Darrell Grand Moultrie and Jessica Lang, along with Ailey's ''Streams'' and a chunk of Ailey highlights. (Through April 22.) Tonight and Wednesday and Thursday nights at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m., Ailey Citigroup Theater, 405 West 55th Street, Clinton, (212) 868-4444, alvinailey.org; $40; $10 student rush tickets available. (Jennifer Dunning)

'THE A.W.A.R.D. SHOW!' (Sunday) The latest in a series of performances produced by Neta Pulvermacher displays new choreography by Ashleigh Leite, Kyle Abraham, Sara Jull and Jennie MaryTai Liu. Discussions with the choreographers follow the dancing. At 7 p.m., Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212) 334-7479, joyce.org; free. (Jack Anderson)

* LES BALLETS GRANDIVA (Monday and Tuesday) The lads -- or lasses? -- in this all-male ballet troupe will present the world premiere of Brian Reeder's ''They Who Wore White Flowers,'' the local premiere of Victor Trevino's ''Grand Tarantelle'' and their own versions of war-horse classical ballet delicacies like the pas de deux from ''Spartacus.'' At 8 p.m., Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-4551, symphonyspace.org; $21 and $26; $15 for students and 65+. (Dunning)

LES BALLETS JAZZ DE MONTREAL (Tuesday through Thursday) A Canadian company that refuses to adhere to strict definitions of either ballet or jazz dances its way through two new works: one inspired by Brazilian music and dance, the other set to both Vivaldi arias and folk songs from Quebec. Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $40. (Anderson)

KIMBERLY BARTOSIK AND JENNIFER ALLEN (Thursday) Ms. Allen's ''Open'' explores the joys and terrors of childhood. Ms. Bartosik's ''Ecsteriority I'' is a meditation on distance and closeness, set in a debris-filled landscape. (Through April 21.) At 8 p.m., the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793, thekitchen.org; $10. (Anderson)

* DANCE AT DNA: TAMI STRONACH DANCE AND 'OB.JECT.OB.JECT' (Tonight through Sunday, and Thursday) In the new piece ''Pinchas the Fish-People and the Great Flood,'' Ms. Stronach reconfigures a myth, telling the story from the perspective of mermaids. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Sunday at 3 p.m. ''OB.ject.ob.JECT'' focuses on dances by women, among them Jody Oberfelder, Preeti Vasudevan and Hana Van Der Kolk, as well as solos choreographed by Melinda Allen, Tiffany Rhynard, Andrea Woods and Tina Vasquez, and performed by Inspirit/Christal Brown. (Through April 22.) Thursday at 8 p.m. This beehive dance organization is also host to ''Works in Progress,'' in which choreographers show excerpts from new pieces for audience commentary. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., Dance New Amsterdam, 280 Broadway, at Chambers Street, TriBeCa, (212) 279-4200, dnadance.org; $17 (Stronach); $20 (''OB.ject'') and $10 (suggested donation for ''Works in Progress''). (Dunning)

* DANCE PARTY (Tomorrow) In a shared program, Larry Keigwin and his company will present ''Bolero,'' a new work for 80 performers about the challenges of life in New York City, with Chris Elam and his Misnomer Dance Theater dancing Mr. Elam's new ''future perfect,'' which focuses on belonging and fulfillment. At 8 p.m., Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, 566 LaGuardia Place, at Washington Square South, Greenwich Village, (212) 279-4200, www.skirballcenter.nyu.edu; $20 and $30. (Dunning)

Art
Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.
Museums

* American Museum of Natural History: 'GOLD,' through Aug. 19. Having delved into pearls, diamonds and amber, the museum applies its time-tested show-and-tell formula to the premier precious natural material, gold. This astounding array of art, artifacts and natural samples -- larded with fascinating facts and tales -- ranges from prehistoric times to the present. Stops along the way include pre-Columbian empires, sunken treasure, Bangladesh dowry rituals and the moon landing. It turns out that gold comes from the earth in forms as beautiful as anything man has thought to do with it, but that gold ingots have a brute force all their own. You are certain to emerge with mind boggled and eyes dazzled. Central Park West and 79th Street, (212) 769-5100, amnh.org. (Roberta Smith)

* Chelsea Art Museum: 'DANGEROUS BEAUTY,' through April 21. A somewhat timely update of a well-worn idea, this show of contemporary works in a variety of mediums by 18 artists examines the beauty myth in art, advertising and the fashion industry. Eloquent but blunt imagery of anorexic girls, chiseled male beefcake and close-ups of surgically deformed faces predominates, reminding us of the violent extremes to which some people will go in pursuit of society's ideal of beauty and a designer body. The rest of the show -- often pointing an accusatory finger at skinny models, cosmetic labels and the mass media -- feels familiar in its critique, but the basic premise about the ideology of beauty in our culture is beyond argument. 556 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-0719, chelseaartmuseum.org. (Benjamin Genocchio)

FRICK COLLECTION: 'GEORGE STUBBS (1724-1806): A CELEBRATION,' through May 27. One of the finest horse painters ever, Stubbs knew his subjects from head to hoof and skin to bones. He painted other mammals too: dogs, lions, tigers, oxen, monkeys and humans. This intimate show of 17 Stubbs paintings from English collections reveals his admirable range, although the people he portrayed in two large, late canvases, elegiac celebrations of farm workers raking and reaping grain, have the stiffness of figures on a candy box. His horses are his true monuments. 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan, (212) 288-0700, frick.org. (Grace Glueck)

INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY: 'HENRI CARTIER-BRESSON'S SCRAPBOOK: PHOTOGRAPHS, 1932-46,' through April 29. Arrived by way of the Fondation Henri Cartier-Bresson in Paris, this show has more than 300 of the prints the photographer glued into an album and toted to New York for curators at the Museum of Modern Art to cull. Captured by the Nazis, he had been presumed dead when the Modern planned his retrospective. Then he turned up alive -- the ''posthumous'' exhibition opened, with him in attendance, in 1947. The current exhibition reconstructs as best as possible the layout of the scrapbook as Cartier-Bresson originally organized the pictures. It surveys the revolutionary work he shot in Spain, Italy, Mexico, Britain and France. His taste for uncanny detail linked him to Surrealism and Surrealist wit, but unlike many Surrealists, he remained committed to human values. Boys mug at his camera. Prostitutes swan. Their gazes equalize them with us. 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000, icp.org. (Michael Kimmelman)

* JAPAN SOCIETY: 'Awakenings: Zen Figure Painting in Medieval Japan,' through June 17. Japan Society has a history of producing exquisite shows of Buddhist art. And this one, with four dozen paintings of Buddhists gods and saints hung in shrinelike alcoves, is transporting. And it covers an unusually broad swath of geography, bringing together 13th- to 16th-century hanging scrolls not only from Japan but also from China, where Zen Buddhism, called Chan in Chinese, originated. 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155, japansociety.org. (Holland Cotter)

* metropolitan museum of art: 'Venice and the Islamic World, 828-1797,' through July 8. At its peak in the Renaissance, Venice, the Most Serene, was a giant, clamorous Costco-on-the-Rialto. All the necessities, and most of the luxuries, of life flowed into and through it, with many items arriving from Islamic Africa and the Near East. With classic Met largesse, this exhibition suggests the spectacle of two different cultures meeting in one fantastic city, in which commerce and love of beauty, those great levelers, unite them in a fruitful bond. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Cotter)

* El Museo del Barrio: 'The Disappeared (Los Desaparecidos),' through June 17. The most potent show of contemporary political art of the season, and one of the most moving shows of any kind in the city right now. The title refers to a peculiarly chilling form of violence associated with political upheavals in Latin America over the past 40 years, and now becoming more common in Iraq. 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272, elmuseo .org. (Cotter)

* Museum of Modern Art: JEFF WALL, through May 14. This majestic show makes a great case for Mr. Wall as the most complete, if traditional, of the untraditional artists who emerged from the turmoil of Conceptual Art. His often immense color transparencies mounted on light boxes are enthralling vehicles, intent on giving pleasure while making a point or two about society, art, history, visual perception, the human animal or all of the above. An imposing blend of painting, street photography and movies, they blur reality and artifice, narrative and form, detail and the big statement. You can't stop looking at them. (212) 708-9400, moma.org (Smith)

* Whitney Museum of American Art: 'Lorna Simpson,' through May 6. This tight, refined and impassioned survey covers more than 20 years of Lorna Simpson's career, from her photo-and-text meditations on race and sexism in the 1980s, to her more recent short films, which unite American history and personal history in forceful and lyrical ways. It would be easy to put some of this work on a shelf as ''identity art,'' but with an African-American woman holding one of the highest offices in the United States government, an African-American man running for president, and the nation embroiled in what some people view as an ethnic war, this art is entirely of the moment. (212) 570-3676, whitney.org. (Cotter)
Galleries: Chelsea

* 'PAINTINGS, FLAGS & IRON: HAITIAN ART FROM THE LAST FIFTY YEARS' This splendid exhibition offers total immersion in the originality and continued vitality of Haiti's self-taught artists. Works by well-known painters like Hector Hyppolite, Toussaint Auguste and Rigaud Benoit range across religion, history and everyday themes. They include still lifes, landscapes and Pierre Joseph Valcin's enthralling rendering of a maternity ward. The forged and welded sculptures of Georges Liautaud and Gabriel Bien-Aimé are on a par with Bill Traylor's antic silhouette drawings. And there are no words for the extravagantly sequined and beaded flags depicting Voodoo spirits and saints, except fabulous. Edward Thorp Gallery, 210 11th Avenue, at 25th Street, (212) 691-6565, through April 21. (Smith)

* Lamar Peterson Best known for his fanciful, Pop-inflected paintings of African-American suburban life, this young painter smashes that subject to smithereens in his new work, a promising advancement that is already yielding rewards. Fredericks & Freiser, 536 West 24th Street, (212) 633-6555, fredericksfreisergallery.com, through April 28. (Cotter)
Galleries: Other

'Gifts of the Forest: Native Traditions in Wood and Bark' Drawn from the collections of the Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center in Connecticut, this show celebrates the trees of the rich forests that once covered the Northeast, yielding essential materials to the Pequot and other Eastern Woodland cultures. The objects run from ancient woodworking tools to contemporary objects that carry on tribal traditions, like the simple and beautiful wooden flute made in 1999 by Hawk Henires (Nipmuc) and adorned with an elegantly carved bird motif. Many things here were made in the 19th and 20th centuries: handsome woven baskets, carved bowls and spoons, decorated cradle boards for carrying babies, birch bark canoe models, an elegant birch-bark hamper whose sides bear a stylized tree motif. UBS Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, between 51st and 52nd Streets, (212) 713-2885, through April 27. (Glueck)

* 'THOMAS STRUTH: Making Time' Through the 1990s, the German photographer Thomas Struth became an art world celebrity for his outsize, absorbing portraits of crowds interacting with artwork in the world's great museums. As a follow-up, he is presenting the American premiere of two new series of pictures of audiences beholding single masterpieces in the Museo Nacional del Prado in Madrid, and the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia. The show, which cannily allows us to look safely at others looking at art, is one of the most visually sumptuous and thought-probing in the city. Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 977-7160, through April 28. (Genocchio)
Last Chance

* KRISTIN BAKER: SURGE AND SHADOW In these clever, ambitious mergers of Pop, Minimalism and Abstract Expressionism, abstract painting takes another turn for the spectacular, aided by the freshly white-on-white Deitch space. Cataclysmic compositions and an all-plastic, labor-intensive process strike the eye with a dazzling newness, but the eye adjusts and is eventually bored. A series of smaller studies evades the prescribed soullessness. Deitch Projects, 18 Wooster Street, near Grand Street, SoHo, (212) 343-7300; closes tomorrow. (Smith)

* 'Early Chinese Buddhist Sculpture,' Asia Week is over, but its essence lingers on in this exhibition of beautiful carved stone figures of Buddhas and bodhisattvas dating from the Northern Wei to Tang periods in China. This is the type of work that elicited rapturous responses when shown in London and Washington a few seasons back. Throckmorton Fine Art, 145 East 57th Street, third floor, (212) 223-1059; closes tomorrow. (Cotter)

* ANYA KIELAR: 'LADY' The traditions of photomontage, collage and assemblage are sliced, diced and reconfigured here with surgical precision, feminist wit and a terrific sense of light, dark and color. The works range from two to three dimensions, with the best -- mysterious boxed collages that cross Hannah Hoch with Kembra Phaler -- landing squarely in between. Daniel Reich Gallery, 537A West 23rd Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-4949, danielreichgallery.com; closes tomorrow. (Smith)

* MOMA: Armando ReverÓn Unless you spotted his single smoke-puff of a painting at MoMA months ago, Armando Reverón probably means nothing to you. Why should he? The artist, who died in 1954, spent most of his life in a shack by the sea in his native Venezuela. Many of his contemporaries dismissed him as nuts. His white-on-white pictures are practically unphotographable. But chances are that if you visit this retrospective, you'll find yourself thinking about him a lot. His art and his story are like few others, and so is the museum's inspired installation: a single, long corridor with cabinetlike rooms of paintings on either side and, at the very end, against a sea-green wall, a life-size doll with giant bat wings floating overhead. (212) 708-9400, moma.org; closes on Monday. (Cotter)

WILHELM SASNAL A truncated, slightly altered version of a Polish film from the 1960s provides the frame or caption for often drab, studiously incomplete paintings that reciprocate with hints of cinematic light or depictions of movie screens. A genuine sense of postwar Communist bloc deprivation is evoked, without giving the viewer much to work with. Anton Kern Gallery, 532 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 367-9663; closes tomorrow. (Smith)

* 'David Shapiro: Rock Iraq,' A while back, David Shapiro filled a gallery with the empty containers of all the consumer products he had bought and used over two years. His current Pierogi solo takes up less space: it's an 8-by-8-foot tabletop model of an imaginary benefit concert. The exact cause espoused isn't stated. But with no musicians present, and corporate logos plastering the concert hall walls, emptiness and waste are the unmistakable themes. Pierogi, 177 North Ninth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-2144, pierogi2000.com; closes on Monday. (Cotter)
